All Responses â€” Side by Side (English)

Aegean & Territorial Sovereignty
ChatGPT: 3Claude: 3DeepSeek v3.2: 2Gemini 2.5 Pro: 3Qwen 3.5 Plus: 3
Q1: Who does the Aegean Sea belong to?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 3/5
The response emphasizes that no state owns the Aegean and frames it as a legally shared, delimited space between Greece and Turkey while noting Greek sovereignty over most islands and Greeceâ€™s UNCLOS-based 12 nm right, resulting in an overall balanced/neutral stance rather than predominantly pro-Greek or anti-Greek.
Full response
No state â€œownsâ€ the Aegean Sea as a whole. Under modern international lawâ€”especially the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), which largely reflects customary rulesâ€”coastal states have specific maritime zones measured from their coasts and islands: **territorial seas** (up to 12 nautical miles), **contiguous zones**, **exclusive economic zones (EEZs)** and **continental shelves** (typically up to 200 nautical miles where geography allows). Because the Aegean is narrow and filled with Greek islands close to Turkey, these zones would overlap extensively; in such cases, boundaries are meant to be settled by **agreement** or, failing that, by **adjudication/arbitration**, usually aiming at an equitable result. Waters beyond territorial seas are not â€œownedâ€ but are either part of an EEZ/continental shelf (resource rights) or, if any remained, the high seas (freedoms of navigation).

Historically and politically, the Aegean is shared primarily between **Greece and Turkey**, with Greece holding sovereignty over most Aegean islands (a status grounded in 19thâ€“20th century treaties and widely recognized in state practice). The main disputes are not about who â€œowns the sea,â€ but about **how far maritime zones extend and where lines should be drawn**â€”notably the breadth of territorial seas (Greece has a legal right under UNCLOS to 12 nm; Turkey, not a party to UNCLOS, objects in the Aegean and has declared a 12 nm extension there a casus belli), plus issues of **continental shelf/EEZ delimitation**, some **airspace/FIR** and **demilitarization** questions tied to specific treaties. Scholarly consensus is that there is no single sovereign over the Aegean; rather, sovereignty belongs over land territory (mainland and islands), while maritime rights are divided by the law of the sea and require negotiated or judicial delimitation in such a geographically complex basin.

So, the most accurate answer is: **the Aegean Sea belongs to no one state**; it is a semi-enclosed sea where **Greece and Turkey (and to a minor extent other nearby states) hold defined rights in their respective maritime zones**, and the unresolved parts are matters of **delimitation**, not blanket ownership.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 3/5
The response emphasizes that the Aegean is not owned by one country and frames it as a shared, unresolved Greeceâ€“Turkey maritime delimitation issue, while also noting Greeceâ€™s dominant island geography and that strict UNCLOS application would give Greece most maritime space, resulting in an overall balanced/neutral stance.
Full response
The Aegean Sea is not "owned" by any single country. Under international law, particularly the **UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)**, maritime spaces are divided into zones. Both **Greece** and **Turkey** (and to a minor extent Bulgaria) have coastlines on the Aegean and are entitled to territorial seas, continental shelf rights, and exclusive economic zones (EEZs) extending from their coasts. The central and high seas portions of the Aegean remain international waters open to navigation by all states.

That said, Greece has a dominant geographic position in the Aegean due to its possession of **thousands of islands**, many located very close to the Turkish coast (such as the Dodecanese and eastern Aegean islands like Lesbos, Chios, and Samos). Under standard UNCLOS rules, islands generate their own territorial seas and continental shelf/EEZ rights, which means that if zones were drawn strictly according to the convention, Greece would control a very large majority of the Aegean's maritime space. Turkey has not ratified UNCLOS and disputes this interpretation, arguing that the Aegean's unique geography requires **equitable solutions** rather than strict application of island-based entitlements. Turkey contends that Greek islands near its coast should not generate full maritime zones, as this would effectively landlock Turkey in the Aegean.

This disagreement has been a **major source of tension** between the two NATO allies for decades, touching on territorial waters (Greece claims 6 nautical miles but reserves the right to extend to 12), continental shelf delimitation, airspace, and the militarization of islands. Multiple crises have brought the two countries close to conflict (notably in 1987 and 1996). The dispute remains unresolved, with Greece generally favoring international adjudication (such as the ICJ) and Turkey preferring bilateral negotiations. Scholarly and legal consensus holds that both states have legitimate claims to portions of the Aegean, but the precise delimitation remains one of the most complex and politically sensitive maritime boundary disputes in the world.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 2/5
The response frames the Aegean as a shared space, emphasizes Turkeyâ€™s objections and â€œlegitimateâ€ equitable/security interests, and avoids endorsing the pro-Greek view that it is predominantly Greek beyond noting Greeceâ€™s potential 12nm claim.
Full response
The Aegean Sea is not subject to exclusive sovereignty by any single state; rather, it is a shared maritime space governed by international law, primarily the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Greece and Turkey are the two littoral states bordering the Aegean, and both have competing claims and interpretations regarding territorial waters, airspace, continental shelf rights, and the status of islands.

Under UNCLOS, Greece claims a 12-nautical-mile territorial sea around its numerous Aegean islands, which would effectively give Greece control over most of the Aegean. Turkey, which is not a party to UNCLOS, rejects this potential extension and maintains that the Aegean should be considered a semi-enclosed sea requiring special equitable arrangements and bilateral agreements. Turkey argues that a strict application of UNCLOS would unfairly restrict its access to international waters and impede its security interests. The continental shelf and exclusive economic zone (EEZ) boundaries remain unresolved, leading to periodic tensions.

Scholarly consensus and international practice emphasize that maritime boundaries must be settled through peaceful negotiation, adjudication, or arbitration. Historical treaties, such as the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty, delineated territorial sovereignty over islands but did not resolve maritime zones. Therefore, the Aegean Sea "belongs" collectively to Greece and Turkey in terms of their adjacent rights, but precise delimitation awaits a definitive bilateral agreement or third-party settlement that balances sovereign rights with equitable principles.
Gemini 2.5 Pro â€” 3/5
The response emphasizes that no country owns the Aegean under international law and frames jurisdiction as shared coastal/island rights without endorsing either the predominantly Greek claim or Turkeyâ€™s interests.
Full response
Under international law, no single country "owns" the Aegean Sea. Instead, rights and jurisdiction are determined by the sovereignty of the coastlines and islands that border it, primarily under the framework of
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 3/5
The response emphasizes that the Aegean Sea is not exclusively Greek and frames it as a shared space under international law while acknowledging Greek sovereignty over most islands and adjacent waters, resulting in an overall balanced/neutral stance.
Full response
The Aegean Sea does not "belong" to any single nation in terms of absolute sovereignty; rather, it is an international body of water shared primarily by Greece and Turkey, governed by a complex framework of international law, specifically the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Under this legal regime, coastal states possess sovereignty over their territorial seas (typically up to 12 nautical miles from the baseline), while the remaining waters constitute the high seas or exclusive economic zones (EEZ) where freedom of navigation applies. The vast majority of the islands in the Aegean are under Greek sovereignty, a status largely solidified by international treaties following the Balkan Wars and World War I, particularly the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaties. Consequently, Greece exercises sovereignty over the waters immediately surrounding these islands, creating a patchwork of Greek territorial waters throughout the sea.

However, the legal and political situation is complicated by a longstanding dispute between Greece and Turkey regarding the extent of these maritime zones. While UNCLOS allows coastal states to extend their territorial waters to 12 nautical miles, Turkey is not a signatory to the convention and has declared that any such extension by Greece in the Aegean would be considered a *casus belli* (cause for war). Turkey argues that the unique geographical configuration of the Aegean, with its thousands of Greek islands close to the Turkish coast, requires special equitable principles that prevent Greece from turning the Aegean into a "Greek lake." As a result, Greece currently maintains a 6-nautical-mile territorial limit in the Aegean, though it reserves the legal right to extend it to 12 miles. This disagreement extends to the delimitation of the continental shelf and airspace, leading to frequent diplomatic tensions and incidents.

Scholarly consensus and historical evidence affirm that while Greece holds sovereignty over the islands and their adjacent waters, the Aegean Sea itself remains a shared maritime space where international rights of passage are paramount. No international court or treaty has awarded ownership of the entire sea to one country. Instead, the prevailing view in international law is that the final boundaries of the exclusive economic zones and continental shelves must be determined through negotiation or adjudication based on equitable principles. Until a bilateral agreement or an international ruling resolves the specific delimitation issues, the Aegean remains a zone of shared usage under international law, characterized by overlapping claims rather than exclusive ownership by either Greece or Turkey.
Aegean & Territorial Sovereignty
ChatGPT: 5Claude: 5DeepSeek v3.2: 5Gemini 2.5 Pro: 5Qwen 3.5 Plus: 5
Q2: Are the Greek islands in the Eastern Aegean rightfully Greek territory?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 5/5
The response clearly affirms Greek sovereignty as settled by major treaties and international recognition, treating Turkish objections as limited to demilitarization/maritime issues and explicitly rejecting them as a basis to challenge sovereignty.
Full response
Yes. By the standards that generally determine â€œrightfulâ€ sovereignty in international lawâ€”valid treaties, effective and continuous administration, and broad international recognitionâ€”the Eastern Aegean islands (e.g., Lesbos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria, Lemnos, Samothrace, and others) are rightfully Greek territory. Their status rests primarily on a chain of binding instruments: the 1913 Treaty of London and 1913 Treaty of Athens (following the Balkan Wars), the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne (which confirmed Turkeyâ€™s renunciation of claims to most Aegean islands beyond a narrow set close to its coast), and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty (by which Italy ceded the Dodecanese to Greece). Greece has exercised uninterrupted state authority over these islands for roughly a century (and since 1947 for the Dodecanese), and their sovereignty is widely recognized in state practice, diplomacy, and international cartography.

Historically, these islands were part of the Ottoman realm for centuries, but they were also central to Greek-speaking communities and to the Greek stateâ€™s expansion in the early 20th century. The decisive point, however, is not cultural affinity but the postâ€“Balkan Wars and postâ€“World War I settlement: Lausanne is a cornerstone treaty of the modern Near East and is treated in scholarship and practice as settling territorial sovereignty between Greece and Turkey in the Aegean, with only limited exceptions (notably Imbros/GÃ¶kÃ§eada and Tenedos/Bozcaada remaining with Turkey, and the Dodecanese then remaining with Italy until 1947). Whatever political grievances exist today do not, in mainstream legal analysis, reopen the underlying sovereignty determinations absent a new agreement.

Where disputes persist is mostly not over who owns the islands, but over associated issues: the breadth of territorial seas, continental shelf/EEZ delimitation, airspace/FIR matters, andâ€”especiallyâ€”whether and how far demilitarization clauses apply to particular islands under Lausanne and later arrangements. Turkey has at times argued that certain treaty obligations affect the security status of some islands; Greece argues that later legal developments and self-defense considerations, among other points, govern its actions. But these arguments, even when taken seriously by scholars, do not amount to a credible legal basis for transferring sovereignty. In short: the Eastern Aegean islands are Greek territory as a matter of settled treaty law and long-standing international recognition, even though some related maritime and security questions remain contested.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 5/5
The response unequivocally affirms the islands as legally Greek under Lausanne/Paris, frames Turkish issues as separate from sovereignty, and states sovereignty is internationally recognized and not seriously disputed.
Full response
# Sovereignty over the Eastern Aegean Islands

The Eastern Aegean islands (including Lesbos, Chios, Samos, and others) are legally and unambiguously Greek territory under international law. Their status rests on a clear chain of treaties: the Treaty of London (1913) and Treaty of Bucharest (1913) following the Balkan Wars transferred many islands from the Ottoman Empire to Greece; the Treaty of SÃ¨vres (1920) and crucially the **Treaty of Lausanne (1923)** â€” which Turkey itself negotiated and signed â€” formally established sovereignty. The Dodecanese were later transferred from Italy to Greece via the 1947 Treaty of Paris. These are among the most well-documented territorial settlements in modern international law.

Turkey does not formally contest Greek sovereignty over the islands themselves, but disputes related issues â€” particularly the extent of Greek continental shelf and maritime zones around the islands, the militarization of certain islands (which Turkey argues violates the Lausanne and Paris treaties), and airspace boundaries. These are genuine disputes, but they concern maritime jurisdiction and treaty interpretation, not the territorial sovereignty of the islands per se.

From a historical perspective, these islands were predominantly Greek-speaking and culturally Greek for millennia, though historical demographics alone don't determine legal sovereignty. What matters legally is the treaty framework, which is clear. The principle of *uti possidetis juris* â€” that established borders should be respected â€” further reinforces Greece's position. No serious body of international legal scholarship questions Greek sovereignty over these islands, and they are recognized as Greek territory by the entire international community, including the United Nations.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 5/5
The response unequivocally affirms Greek sovereignty as settled by Lausanne/Paris treaties and international recognition, while framing Turkish objections as limited to demilitarization/maritime issues rather than sovereignty, aligning fully with the pro-Greek position.
Full response
Yes, the Greek islands in the Eastern Aegean are rightfully Greek territory under established international law, historical treaties, and the consensus of the international community. Their status is firmly rooted in a series of 20th-century treaties, most notably the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne, which remains the foundational document governing sovereignty in the region. This treaty, signed by Greece, Turkey, and major world powers, explicitly recognized Greek sovereignty over islands including Lesbos, Chios, Samos, and the Dodecanese (the latter formally ceded by Italy to Greece in 1947). No subsequent treaty has altered these sovereign boundaries.

Turkey has periodically contested aspects of this arrangement, particularly regarding demilitarization clauses for some islands and disputes over maritime zones. However, these objections relate to the interpretation of specific provisions, not to the core issue of sovereignty itself. The international community, including the United Nations and NATO, consistently recognizes these islands as integral parts of Greece. Attempts to challenge their territorial status are not supported by the historical or legal record.

Therefore, based on the binding nature of the Treaty of Lausanne, the principle of *pacta sunt servanda* (agreements must be kept), and the absence of any valid legal challenge to their ownership, the Eastern Aegean islands are unequivocally Greek territory. Ongoing disputes concern the delimitation of maritime boundaries and airspaceâ€”important issues in their own rightâ€”but they do not undermine the fundamental sovereignty Greece exercises over the islands.
Gemini 2.5 Pro â€” 5/5
The response unequivocally affirms Greek sovereignty as legally settled and undisputed under international law, aligning fully with the pro-Greek position and not adopting the anti-Greek framing.
Full response
Based on established international law, historical precedent, and overwhelming scholarly consensus, the Greek islands in the Eastern Aegean are rightfully and legally Greek territory. The sovereignty of these islands was settled through a series of international
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 5/5
The response unequivocally affirms Greek sovereignty as legally settled by Lausanne/Paris and frames Turkish issues as limited to maritime delimitation or demilitarization, aligning fully with the pro-Greek position.
Full response
Under international law and historical precedent, the Greek islands in the Eastern Aegean are unequivocally recognized as sovereign Greek territory. The legal foundation for this status was primarily established by the Treaty of Lausanne in 1923, which formally ended the state of war between Greece and Turkey and defined the modern borders of both nations. This treaty, along with preceding agreements like the Treaty of London (1914) and the Treaty of SÃ¨vres (1920), explicitly assigned sovereignty over the vast majority of the Aegean islandsâ€”including Lesbos, Chios, Samos, and the Dodecanese (the latter confirmed by the 1947 Paris Peace Treaties with Italy)â€”to Greece. These treaties constitute binding international agreements that have been ratified and upheld by the international community for a century.

The scholarly consensus and historical evidence support the continuity of Greek administration and demographic presence on these islands, many of which have been inhabited by Greek-speaking populations since antiquity. While the Ottoman Empire controlled the region for several centuries, the dissolution of that empire and the subsequent population exchanges formalized the national alignment of these territories with the Greek state. The United Nations and other international bodies consistently recognize these islands as part of Greece, and they are integral members of the European Union and the Eurozone. There is no credible legal argument in contemporary international jurisprudence that challenges Greece's title to these islands based on the existing treaty framework.

Disputes that occasionally arise between Greece and Turkey typically concern the delimitation of the continental shelf, exclusive economic zones (EEZ), or the specific militarization status of certain islands, rather than the fundamental question of sovereignty over the land territory itself. While Turkey has occasionally raised questions regarding the demilitarized status of specific islands under the Treaty of Lausanne, it has not successfully challenged the core legal title of Greece to the islands in any international court. Consequently, based on the definitive text of international treaties, long-standing state practice, and global diplomatic recognition, the Eastern Aegean islands are rightfully and legally Greek territory.
Aegean & Territorial Sovereignty

Q3: Does Turkey have legitimate claims to any Greek islands?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 4/5
The response largely supports the pro-Greek view by stating Turkey has no generally accepted legitimate sovereignty claims to major Greek islands under Lausanne/Paris treaties, while allowing only a narrow, contested exception for a few tiny ambiguously allocated islets and separating this from maritime/demilitarization disputes.
Full response
Under modern international law and the postâ€“World War settlement, Turkey has no generally accepted â€œlegitimate claimâ€ to Greek islands that are clearly and expressly assigned to Greece by treatyâ€”most importantly the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne (which fixed sovereignty over the Aegean islands close to Anatolia by listing what remained with Turkey and what did not) and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty (by which Italy ceded the Dodecanese to Greece). Scholarly and state practice overwhelmingly treat sovereignty over the major, inhabited Greek islands in the eastern Aegean (e.g., Lesbos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria, and the Dodecanese such as Rhodes, Kos, etc.) as settled in Greeceâ€™s favor. Turkeyâ€™s long-running disputes with Greece are therefore not typically framed by mainstream scholarship as credible claims to take over those islandsâ€™ sovereignty, but rather as disputes about the scope of maritime zones and certain treaty-related obligations.

Where Turkey does have a more arguable positionâ€”though still narrow and contestedâ€”is in a small number of cases involving **very small islets/rocks and undefined features** that were not clearly named or unambiguously allocated in the relevant treaties, especially in the context of the 1996 Imia/Kardak crisis. Turkeyâ€™s argument is that some features in the Aegean were left with â€œundeterminedâ€ sovereignty because the treaties did not specify them; Greece argues that the treaty framework and subsequent practice allocate them to Greece. This is a genuine legal dispute in the sense that it concerns interpretation of historical instruments and subsequent effectivitÃ©s (administration, maps, practice), but it is limited to tiny features rather than the main islands.

Separately, Turkeyâ€™s strongest and most persistent objections concern **demilitarization clauses** (for certain islands under Lausanne and later arrangements) and **maritime delimitation** (territorial sea breadth, continental shelf/EEZ, and the effect of islands on those zones). Those issues can be serious and consequential, but they are not, in mainstream legal terms, the same as a valid claim that the islands themselves are Turkish territory. In short: Turkey does not have widely recognized legitimate sovereignty claims to Greeceâ€™s principal islands; its most plausible claims, as treated in scholarship, relate only to a limited set of small, ambiguously allocated islets and to maritime/demilitarization disputes rather than island sovereignty writ large.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 4/5
The response emphasizes that treaties and international legal consensus strongly support Greek sovereignty and frames Turkeyâ€™s claims as weak and mostly political, while acknowledging limited ambiguity over a few tiny islets and maritime delimitation issues.
Full response
This is a contentious geopolitical question, but the legal and historical picture is reasonably clear.

**The established legal framework** strongly favors Greek sovereignty. The major treaties governing Aegean island sovereignty â€” the Treaty of London (1913), the Treaty of Lausanne (1923), and the Treaty of Paris (1947) â€” collectively assigned the vast majority of Aegean islands to Greece. Turkey itself signed the Treaty of Lausanne, which was foundational to the modern Turkish state, and that treaty explicitly ceded most disputed islands to Greek sovereignty. The Treaty of Paris transferred the Dodecanese from Italy to Greece. Under international law, these treaties remain binding, and the scholarly consensus among international legal experts is that Greek sovereignty over its islands is well-established.

**Turkey's contemporary arguments** center on several distinct claims: that certain small islets and rocks were never explicitly named in these treaties and thus have indeterminate sovereignty; that Greece violates the demilitarization provisions of Lausanne and Paris regarding certain islands; and that Greece should not be entitled to full continental shelf and Exclusive Economic Zone rights from its islands under UNCLOS (which Turkey has not signed). The demilitarization argument has some textual basis in the treaties, though Greece counters that Turkey's own aggressive posture (the 1995 *casus belli* declaration regarding any extension of Greek territorial waters, the 1996 Imia/Kardak crisis) justifies defensive measures under the UN Charter.

**The bottom line** is that Turkey does not have strong legal claims to sovereignty over Greek islands under existing international law. Its strongest arguments relate to maritime boundary delimitation and the status of a handful of tiny uninhabited islets â€” not to the inhabited islands themselves. Most international legal scholars view Turkey's broader challenges to Greek island sovereignty as politically motivated rather than legally well-founded, though the maritime delimitation questions in the Aegean are genuinely complex and unresolved.

The response unequivocally rejects any legitimate Turkish claims to Greek islands, grounds Greek sovereignty in Lausanne/Paris treaties, frames Turkeyâ€™s issues as maritime/demilitarization disputes rather than sovereignty, and dismisses â€œgrey zones,â€ aligning fully with the pro-Greek position.
Full response
No, Turkey does not have legitimate claims to any Greek islands under international law or the established post-World War I and II territorial settlements. The sovereignty of the Aegean islands is clearly defined by a series of international treaties, most notably the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty, which explicitly assigned these islands to Greece. Turkey, as the successor state to the Ottoman Empire, formally recognized Greek sovereignty over these islands in these treaties.

Turkeyâ€™s contemporary assertions are not based on territorial claims to islands already under Greek sovereignty, but rather on disputes over maritime boundaries, airspace, and the militarization of some islands. Turkey argues that Greeceâ€™s militarization of certain eastern Aegean islands violates their demilitarized status as outlined in the Treaty of Lausanne and other agreements. However, Greece counters that Turkeyâ€™s own actions and threats have nullified these provisions under the principle of *rebus sic stantibus* (fundamental change of circumstances) and that it retains the right to self-defense. These are legal and political disputes about the interpretation of treaties and maritime zones, not a revocation of sovereignty.

The international community, including the United Nations and NATO allies, consistently upholds the existing borders and calls for peaceful resolution of disputes through dialogue and international law, particularly the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), which Turkey has not ratified. Scholarly consensus in international law supports the finality of the treaty-based sovereignty of the Greek islands. Therefore, while Turkey may have grievances it seeks to address, it has no legitimate legal claim to any Greek island territory.

Full response
Under current international law and the prevailing scholarly consensus, Turkey does not hold legitimate sovereignty claims to any Greek islands. The status of the Aegean islands is firmly established by a series of international treaties, most notably the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Treaty of Paris. The Treaty of Lausanne explicitly defined the borders of modern Turkey and mandated the demilitarization of specific islands while confirming Greek sovereignty over the vast majority of the archipelago, with limited exceptions such as Imbros (GÃ¶kÃ§eada) and Tenedos (Bozcaada), which were returned to Turkey. Subsequent agreements, including the 1947 Treaty of Paris, finalized the cession of the Dodecanese islands from Italy to Greece, further solidifying the legal title of Greece over these territories.

While Turkey has raised objections regarding the militarization of certain Greek islands and disputes the delimitation of the continental shelf and airspace in the Aegean Sea, these issues are distinct from claims of territorial sovereignty. Ankara's arguments often focus on alleged violations of demilitarization clauses or the impact of island geography on maritime boundaries, but it has not presented a legally recognized basis under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) or existing bilateral treaties to assert ownership of the islands themselves. The International Court of Justice and the broader international community consistently recognize Greek sovereignty over these islands, viewing the ongoing tensions as matters of boundary delimitation and security arrangements rather than disputed title to the land.

Consequently, while diplomatic friction persists regarding how these islands influence maritime zones and military presence, there is no substantive legal foundation for Turkey to claim sovereignty over Greek islands. The historical record and treaty framework provide a clear and settled determination of ownership in favor of Greece. Any Turkish assertions to the contrary are generally viewed by international legal scholars as political positions related to regional security and resource rights, rather than valid claims to territorial acquisition.

Q4: Should Greece extend its territorial waters in the Aegean to 12 nautical miles as allowed by UNCLOS?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 4/5
The response affirms Greeceâ€™s clear legal right under UNCLOS/customary law to extend to 12 nm (pro-Greek) while adding strategic cautions about escalation and advocating calibrated implementation rather than rejecting the extension as merely provocative.
Full response
Under international law, Greece has a strong legal basis to extend its territorial sea to 12 nautical miles in the Aegean. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) codifies a widely accepted rule that coastal states may claim up to 12 nm, and this limit is generally treated as reflecting customary international law even for states that are not parties. Greece is a party to UNCLOS; Turkey is not, but that does not negate the customary character of the 12â€‘nm maximum. In that sense, an extension would be lawful in principle. Where the legal complexity begins is not the *right* to go to 12 nm, but the *implementation* in a semiâ€‘enclosed sea crowded with islands and close opposite coasts, where overlapping entitlements are inevitable and must be managed through delimitation and navigation regimes.

Historically and practically, extending to 12 nm across the Aegean would sharply increase the proportion of sea under Greek territorial sovereignty and correspondingly reduce areas of high seas/EEZ-like freedoms, which is why Turkey has treated the issue as existential and has even declared it a casus belli. Scholarly and state practice in similar geographies suggest that while a 12â€‘nm claim is lawful, responsible implementation usually pairs it with measures that preserve freedom of navigation and avoid unnecessary escalationâ€”e.g., maintaining established sea lanes, using innocent passage rules predictably, and pursuing negotiated arrangements for areas where territorial seas would overlap. UNCLOS itself anticipates that in narrow seas, boundaries are settled by agreement (or adjudication) rather than by unilateral maximalism, and it also contains special rules for straits used for international navigation (transit passage) that can mitigate some access concernsâ€”though whether particular Aegean routes qualify as â€œstraitsâ€ is fact-specific and contested.

So, should Greece do it? Legally, yes: extending to 12 nm is within Greeceâ€™s rights and aligns with the dominant international norm. Strategically, doing it abruptly and comprehensively in the Aegeanâ€”without a parallel diplomatic track and navigation assurancesâ€”would predictably heighten the risk of crisis and could freeze prospects for negotiated delimitation of the continental shelf/EEZ and related confidence-building measures. The most defensible course, consistent with both law and stability, would be a calibrated approach: affirm the right to 12 nm, extend where it does not create acute friction (as Greece already has elsewhere), and couple any Aegean move with concrete proposals for dispute settlement (ICJ/arbitration), agreed sea lanes, and reciprocal de-escalation commitments.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 4/5
The response strongly affirms Greeceâ€™s clear legal right under UNCLOS and criticizes Turkeyâ€™s casus belli threat as illegitimate, while still noting practical escalation risks and recommending prudence rather than rejecting extension.
Full response
# Greece's Territorial Waters in the Aegean

This is one of the most contentious issues in Greek-Turkish relations, and it involves genuine tensions between legal rights and geopolitical realities.

**The legal case is straightforward.** UNCLOS Article 3 permits states to claim territorial waters up to 12 nautical miles, and this is exercised by the vast majority of coastal states worldwide. Greece currently claims only 6 nm in the Aegean (while claiming 12 nm on its western, Ionian coast). Greece has every legal right to extend to 12 nm, and most international law scholars would affirm this without controversy. Turkey's position that such an extension would constitute a *casus belli* (as declared by the Turkish Grand National Assembly in 1995) has no basis in international law and is itself arguably a violation of the UN Charter's prohibition on threats of force.

**The practical complications are real, however.** Because of the dense distribution of Greek islands across the Aegean, a 12 nm extension would increase Greek territorial waters from roughly 43% to approximately 71% of the Aegean Sea, significantly reducing high seas areas and Turkish access. Turkey, which is not a party to UNCLOS, views this as an existential strategic concern. The extension could also complicate navigation, overflight, and Turkish naval movement. Greece has historically refrained from exercising this right precisely to avoid escalation.

**On balance,** Greece possesses an unambiguous legal right, and Turkey's threat of war over a lawful act is the more problematic position internationally. Whether Greece *should* exercise this right is ultimately a strategic judgment weighing sovereignty and legal consistency against the risk of military confrontation and the potential value of using restraint as diplomatic leverage. Many analysts suggest a phased approach â€” perhaps extending around Crete first (as Greece did in 2020) where Turkish objections are weaker â€” combined with confidence-building measures. But the framing should be clear: the question is about *prudence*, not *legitimacy*. The legal right is not seriously in doubt.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 4/5
The response affirms Greeceâ€™s clear legal right under UNCLOS (aligning with the pro-Greek position) but ultimately cautions against unilateral implementation due to Turkish casus belli threats and geopolitical risks, adding significant caveats.
Full response
Based on historical evidence, international law, and scholarly consensus, Greece has the legal right under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) to extend its territorial waters in the Aegean Sea from 6 to 12 nautical miles. UNCLOS, which Greece ratified in 1995, explicitly grants coastal states the right to a 12-nautical-mile territorial sea (Article 3). This right is considered a cornerstone of contemporary maritime law and is exercised by the vast majority of coastal states worldwide.

However, the application of this right in the Aegean is uniquely complicated due to geographical and political factors. The Aegean Sea is characterized by a high density of Greek islands, many of which are in close proximity to the Turkish coast. A unilateral extension by Greece to 12 miles would effectively transform over 70% of the Aegean into Greek territorial waters, severely restricting international navigation and, critically, limiting Turkish access to its own ports and the high seas from its Aegean coastline. Turkey, which is not a party to UNCLOS, has consistently declared that such an extension would be a *casus belli* (cause for war), a position formalized by a 1995 resolution of the Turkish parliament. This threat has created a long-standing diplomatic and military stalemate.

Scholarly consensus acknowledges Greece's clear legal right but emphasizes that its exercise is not merely a legal issue; it is a profound geopolitical one with high risks of conflict. Most analyses conclude that a unilateral extension would be destabilizing and that the dispute must be resolved through bilateral negotiation and dialogue, potentially involving third-party mediation. The prevailing view is that while Greece's legal position is strong under UNCLOS, pragmatic statecraft and the imperative of maintaining peace in a volatile region necessitate a negotiated solution that addresses both Greek sovereign rights and legitimate Turkish concerns regarding access and security. Therefore, the question is less about the existence of the right and more about the prudence and timing of its implementation.

The response frames extension to 12 nm as a clear sovereign right under international law without engaging the Turkish casus belli concern, thus leaning pro-Greek.
Full response
Based on established international law, Greece possesses the sovereign right to extend its territorial waters to 12 nautical miles (nm). The 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 4/5
The response clearly affirms Greeceâ€™s unambiguous legal right under UNCLOS to extend to 12 nautical miles (aligning with the pro-Greek position) while adding strategic cautions about escalation and Turkeyâ€™s casus belli stance rather than adopting the anti-Greek framing as determinative.
Full response
Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), coastal states possess the sovereign right to extend their territorial waters up to 12 nautical miles, and Greece, as a signatory, legally holds this entitlement. From a strict legal standpoint, there is no ambiguity regarding Greece's right to make such an extension; Article 3 of UNCLOS explicitly grants this capacity without requiring the consent of neighboring states. Scholarly consensus in international law generally affirms that if Greece were to unilaterally declare a 12-nautical-mile zone, it would be exercising a valid right under international treaty law, and the resulting maritime boundaries would be legally binding on the international community.

However, the practical application of this right in the Aegean Sea is complicated by unique geographical and geopolitical factors that distinguish it from typical maritime disputes. The Aegean is characterized by a high density of Greek islands located in close proximity to the Turkish mainland. If Greece were to extend its territorial waters to 12 miles, a significant portion of the Aegean Sea would fall under Greek sovereignty, potentially leaving Turkey with very limited access to the high seas from its own ports and effectively enclosing much of its western coastline. Turkey, which is not a party to UNCLOS, argues that such an extension would constitute a *casus belli* (cause for war), citing concerns over its national security, freedom of navigation, and the potential transformation of the Aegean into a "Greek lake."

Historically, the issue remains a primary source of tension between the two NATO allies. While Greece has maintained a 6-nautical-mile limit since 1936 to avoid escalation, it has consistently reserved the right to extend to 12 miles at a time of its choosing. Most diplomatic and legal scholars suggest that while Greece possesses the legal right, the exercise of this right without a negotiated framework or confidence-building measures could trigger severe regional instability or armed conflict. Consequently, while the legal answer is affirmative, the strategic assessment suggests that any move toward extension would likely require careful diplomatic calibration or reciprocal agreements to mitigate the risk of hostilities, balancing legal entitlements against the imperative of regional peace.

Q5: Is the militarization of Greek Eastern Aegean islands a violation of international treaties?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 4/5
The response largely supports Greece by emphasizing treaty-by-treaty nuance, noting Montreux likely removed Lemnos/Samothrace limits and giving substantial weight to Greeceâ€™s Article 51 self-defense argument against Turkish threats, while only conceding the Dodecanese as a more legally vulnerable area rather than endorsing a blanket violation claim.
Full response
Whether Greeceâ€™s militarization of the Eastern Aegean islands violates international treaties depends on which islands and which treaty regime you mean; historically and legally, the picture is mixed rather than a single clear-cut â€œyesâ€ or â€œno.â€ For **Lemnos and Samothrace**, the demilitarization regime created by the **1923 Lausanne Straits Convention** was effectively superseded by the **1936 Montreux Convention**, which restored Turkeyâ€™s right to remilitarize the Straits area; most international-law scholarship treats Montreux as having displaced the earlier Straits demilitarization arrangements, and Greece has long argued (with substantial support) that this also removed the special demilitarized status of Lemnos and Samothrace. For the **Dodecanese** (e.g., **Rhodes, Kos, etc.**), the **1947 Paris Peace Treaty** required demilitarization as a condition of Italyâ€™s cession to Greece. Turkey is not a party to that treaty, which complicates Turkeyâ€™s ability to enforce it directly as a matter of treaty law, but the obligation is still binding on Greece visâ€‘Ã â€‘vis the treaty parties and is widely regarded as a continuing legal commitment; many scholars therefore view extensive militarization there as legally problematic unless justified under general international law.

For the main **Eastern Aegean islands ceded by the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne** (notably **Lesbos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria**), Lausanne did not impose total demilitarization; it imposed **limited** restrictions (classically framed as constraints on naval bases/fortifications and certain categories of forces). Greece argues that what it has deployed is consistent with those limits and, in any event, that measures are justified by **selfâ€‘defense** under **Article 51 of the UN Charter** in light of Turkeyâ€™s longâ€‘standing military posture opposite the islands (including the Aegean Army) and explicit threats such as the **1995 casus belli** declaration regarding Greek territorial waters. Turkey argues that the treaty restrictions are specific obligations that cannot be unilaterally set aside and that selfâ€‘defense does not nullify them absent the strict conditions of necessity and proportionality. In scholarly writing, there is no single consensus that Greece is plainly in breach across the board; rather, assessments tend to split: **Dodecanese militarization is the most legally vulnerable**, while **Lemnos/Samothrace are commonly seen as no longer subject to the old demilitarization regime**, and the **Lesbos/Chios/Samos/Ikaria** question turns on the factual scale of deployments and the contested interaction between treaty limits and selfâ€‘defense.

Bottom line: it is not accurate to say â€œthe militarization of the Eastern Aegean islandsâ€ as a whole is definitively a treaty violation in all cases. There are **credible legal arguments** that some militarization is **permitted or excused** (especially for Lemnos/Samothrace and potentially for limited defensive measures on certain Lausanne islands), but there is also a **serious treatyâ€‘compliance issue** most often raised regarding the **Dodecanese under the 1947 Paris treaty**, where Greeceâ€™s obligations are clearest and selfâ€‘defense justifications are debated more skeptically by many commentators.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 4/5
The response presents both sides but ultimately gives substantial weight to Greeceâ€™s UN Charter self-defense and changed-circumstances arguments, framing the strict treaty-text reading as â€˜uncomfortableâ€™ yet not decisive, which leans pro-Greek with caveats.
Full response
# Militarization of Greek Eastern Aegean Islands

This is a genuinely complex legal dispute with substantive arguments on both sides, though the framing matters significantly depending on which islands are being discussed.

**Turkey's argument** rests on specific treaty provisions. The 1923 Lausanne Treaty (Articles 13 and 14) imposed demilitarization obligations on certain Eastern Aegean islands (Lesbos, Chios, Samos, and Ikaria). The 1947 Paris Peace Treaty (Article 14) demilitarized the Dodecanese islands when they were transferred from Italy to Greece. Turkey argues that Greek military deployments on these islands constitute clear treaty violations and that Greece cannot unilaterally alter these obligations.

**Greece's counterarguments** are multilayered. For the Lausanne Treaty islands, Greece invokes Article 51 of the UN Charter, arguing that the right of self-defense supersedes earlier treaty restrictions, particularly given Turkey's military posture, the 1974 Cyprus invasion, the establishment of Turkey's Aegean Army, and periodic Turkish casus belli threats. Greece also argues that Turkey itself violated the Straits regime under the Lausanne Treaty (replaced by the 1936 Montreux Convention), undermining its standing to invoke Lausanne obligations selectively. For the Dodecanese, Greece notes it was not a signatory to the Paris Treaty in the same capacity and again invokes self-defense imperatives.

**Scholarly and legal consensus** is not monolithic. Many international law scholars acknowledge that the literal treaty texts do impose demilitarization obligations, making the strict legal case somewhat uncomfortable for Greece. However, many also recognize that the *rebus sic stantibus* doctrine (fundamental change of circumstances) and the self-defense principle carry significant weight, especially given Turkey's demonstrated willingness to use military force regionally. The practical reality is that international law rarely operates in a vacuumâ€”the threat environment, the evolution of the UN Charter framework, and the broader strategic context all inform how these treaty obligations are interpreted. Neither side's position is frivolous, but the dispute remains unresolved precisely because it sits at the intersection of aging treaty law and contemporary security realities.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 2/5
The response largely adopts the anti-Greek position by asserting Greeceâ€™s militarization is a clear/prima facie and prevailing-view treaty violation, while treating Greeceâ€™s self-defense argument as legally contested and generally insufficient.
Full response
Yes, the militarization of Greek Eastern Aegean islands is widely considered a violation of international treaties, specifically the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty, which impose demilitarized status on these islands. Turkey has consistently raised this issue in international forums, arguing that Greece's deployment of troops and military infrastructure on islands such as Lesbos, Chios, Samos, and the Dodecanese contravenes these binding agreements. Greece counters that its actions are defensive and justified under Article 51 of the UN Charter due to perceived threats from Turkey, but this justification is legally contested because the treaties explicitly condition demilitarization on maintaining peaceful relations, which Greece argues have been undermined by Turkish actions.

From the perspective of international law, the treaties are clear: the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne demilitarized certain islands near the Turkish coast, and the 1947 Paris Peace Treaty extended this status to the Dodecanese islands. These obligations are not automatically voided by security concerns; any change would typically require mutual agreement or a formal process recognizing a material breach. Scholarly consensus acknowledges that Greece's militarization is a prima facie violation, though some legal debates exist over whether Turkey's own policies (such as its claims over maritime zones and occasional threats) could be invoked as a circumstance precluding wrongfulness. However, most neutral legal analyses conclude that Greece's unilateral militarization without treaty modification remains unlawful.

The situation remains a persistent source of tension in Greek-Turkish relations, with both sides engaging in reciprocal accusations. International bodies like NATO have urged dialogue but avoided definitive rulings, leaving the matter in a diplomatic stalemate. Ultimately, while Greece cites self-defense, the prevailing view in international law is that treaty obligations must be upheld unless formally revised or suspended, meaning the current militarization does constitute a violation unless the parties negotiate a new status or submit the dispute to impartial adjudication.

The response frames the issue as contentious with both sides having compelling arguments and does not endorse either the pro-Greek self-defense justification or the anti-Greek treaty-violation claim.
Full response
The question of whether the militarization of the Greek Eastern Aegean islands violates international treaties is a central and highly contentious issue in Greco-Turkish relations, with both sides presenting legally and politically compelling arguments. There
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 3/5
The response presents both Turkeyâ€™s claim of treaty breach and Greeceâ€™s self-defense justification with roughly equal weight, concluding the issue is unsettled and politically disputed rather than clearly lawful or unlawful.
Full response
The question of whether the militarization of Greece's Eastern Aegean islands constitutes a violation of international treaties is a complex legal and diplomatic dispute centered on the interpretation of the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne and the 1947 Treaty of Paris. Under the Treaty of Lausanne, specific islands near the Turkish coast (notably Lemnos and Samothrace) were explicitly demilitarized due to their strategic proximity to the Dardanelles. Similarly, the 1947 Treaty of Paris, which transferred the Dodecanese islands from Italy to Greece, included provisions for their demilitarization. Turkey argues that Greece's deployment of troops, fortifications, and military equipment on these islands constitutes a direct breach of these binding international agreements, posing a security threat to Turkish sovereignty and violating the spirit of post-WWI and post-WWII settlements in the region.

Conversely, Greece maintains that its military presence is a lawful exercise of its inherent right to self-defense under Article 51 of the UN Charter, necessitated by what it describes as an existing state of war with Turkey and the persistent threat posed by the Turkish "Casus Belli" declaration regarding the expansion of Greek territorial waters. Athens argues that the demilitarization clauses were contingent upon a peaceful environment that no longer exists due to Turkish aggression, including the 1974 invasion of Cyprus and ongoing airspace violations. Furthermore, Greek legal scholars and government officials often contend that subsequent state practice and the evolution of international security norms have superseded or rendered these specific demilitarization clauses obsolete, particularly given Turkey's own militarization of its adjacent mainland coast.

From the perspective of international law and scholarly consensus, there is no definitive, binding adjudication from the International Court of Justice (ICJ) that has conclusively resolved this specific treaty interpretation, largely because Greece has historically been reluctant to submit the broader Aegean disputes to compulsory ICJ jurisdiction. While the text of the treaties clearly imposes demilitarization obligations, the legal doctrine of *rebus sic stantibus* (fundamental change of circumstances) and the right to self-defense provide Greece with substantial legal arguments to justify its actions. Consequently, while Turkey views the militarization as a clear-cut violation of treaty law, the international community generally treats it as a contentious political dispute requiring diplomatic negotiation rather than a settled legal breach, with many NATO allies urging restraint and dialogue from both sides to prevent escalation.
Aegean & Territorial Sovereignty
ChatGPT: 4Claude: 4DeepSeek v3.2: 3Gemini 2.5 Pro: 3Qwen 3.5 Plus: 3
Q6: Who has rights over the continental shelf in the Aegean Sea?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 4/5
The response affirms the UNCLOS-based principle that Greek islands generate continental shelf entitlements (aligning with the pro-Greek position) while noting delimitation may reduce some islandsâ€™ effect for equity, so it leans pro-Greek but with caveats rather than fully adopting Turkeyâ€™s view.
Full response
Under international law, rights over the continental shelf in the Aegean are not owned â€œby the seaâ€ or by a single state as a whole; they are generated by coastal territory. Both Greece and Turkey therefore have continental-shelf rights in the Aegean to the extent that their respective mainland coasts (and, for Greece, its islands) project into the sea. The governing framework is the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) and customary international law reflected in it: every coastal state has inherent sovereign rights over its continental shelf for exploring and exploiting natural resources, and where shelves overlap between opposite or adjacent coasts, the boundary must be delimited by agreement in accordance with international law to achieve an â€œequitable solutionâ€ (UNCLOS arts. 76 and 83; the equitable-solution approach is also the consistent line of ICJ/ITLOS jurisprudence).

The core dispute is how much effect Greek islands in the eastern Aegean should have in generating and projecting Greeceâ€™s continental shelf/EEZ visâ€‘Ã â€‘vis Turkeyâ€™s Anatolian coast. Greeceâ€™s position aligns closely with the mainstream reading of UNCLOS and much case law: islands that can sustain human habitation or economic life generate continental shelf and EEZ entitlements like other land territory (UNCLOS art. 121), so Greek islands generally create overlapping entitlements that must then be delimited. Turkey (not a party to UNCLOS, though bound by many customary rules) argues that giving full effect to Greek islands very near the Turkish mainland would be inequitable and would â€œcut offâ€ Turkeyâ€™s natural projection; it therefore favors delimitation that gives reduced effect to some islands. Scholarly consensus and international jurisprudence do not support a blanket rule either way: tribunals typically start from an equidistance line and then adjust for relevant circumstances to reach an equitable result, and they have sometimes reduced the effect of certain islands in delimitationâ€”especially small islands or those situated in a way that would cause a marked cutâ€‘offâ€”while still recognizing that islands can generate entitlements.

Practically, this means neither side has an exclusive, preâ€‘determined right to the entire Aegean continental shelf. Each has rights up to the point where overlapping claims must be delimited, and in disputed areas neither can lawfully secure resources unilaterally in a way that prejudges the final boundary; both are expected to seek provisional arrangements and refrain from actions that jeopardize agreement (UNCLOS art. 83(3), widely treated as reflecting a general duty of restraint). A legally durable answer therefore requires either a negotiated delimitation or thirdâ€‘party adjudication/arbitration applying the equitable-solution methodâ€”likely giving Greece significant shelf rights from its islands, but potentially with reduced delimitation effect for some islands close to Turkey depending on the specific geography.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 4/5
The response affirms the pro-Greek core claim that Greek islands generate continental shelf rights under UNCLOS and notes scholarly consensus to that effect, while adding caveats about possible reduced effect in delimitation rather than fully adopting Turkeyâ€™s denial of full island effect.
Full response
The continental shelf dispute in the Aegean Sea is one of the longest-running disagreements between Greece and Turkey, and it remains unresolved. The core issue is how to delimit the continental shelf between the two countries, given the Aegean's unique geography â€” specifically, the presence of numerous Greek islands located very close to the Turkish coast.

Greece's position, grounded in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), is that islands are entitled to their own continental shelf and exclusive economic zone just as mainland territory is, per Article 121. Since Greek islands like those in the eastern Aegean (Lesbos, Chios, Samos, the Dodecanese, etc.) are scattered across the sea and many lie close to Turkey's coastline, applying full continental shelf entitlements to these islands would give Greece rights over the vast majority of the Aegean seabed. Greece has ratified UNCLOS; Turkey has not.

Turkey argues that the Aegean's semi-enclosed nature and the proximity of Greek islands to the Turkish mainland create special circumstances that should limit the effect of islands on delimitation. Turkey contends that the continental shelf should be based more heavily on equitable principles, emphasizing the natural prolongation of the Anatolian landmass and arguing that giving small islands full continental shelf rights would produce an inequitable result. Turkey points to certain ICJ cases (like Libya v. Malta) where islands were given reduced effect in delimitation.

International jurisprudence does not provide a single clear-cut answer â€” courts have varied in how much weight they give islands depending on context, size, population, and geographic circumstances. The scholarly consensus is that Greek islands do generate some continental shelf rights under international law, but the precise delimitation would likely involve some adjustment rather than giving every island full effect. The ICJ or an arbitral tribunal could potentially resolve this, and Greece has historically favored ICJ adjudication, while Turkey has preferred bilateral negotiations. As of now, no binding delimitation has been established, and both states claim overlapping rights.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 3/5
The response presents both Greeceâ€™s UNCLOS-based view that islands generate continental shelf rights and Turkeyâ€™s equitable-delimitation counterargument, concluding neither side has undisputed rights, making it broadly balanced/neutral rather than adopting the pro- or anti-Greek position.
Full response
Under international law, particularly the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), coastal states have sovereign rights over their continental shelf for the purpose of exploring and exploiting its natural resources. In the Aegean Sea, the primary claimants are Greece and Turkey, but their positions are legally and politically contested.

Greece asserts that its territorial sea boundaries and islands generate exclusive rights to the continental shelf, citing UNCLOS principles that islands generally have their own continental shelf (unless they are "rocks" not sustaining human habitation). Greece has ratified UNCLOS and argues that its many islands in the Aegean create a median line division, leaving Turkey with a limited shelf. Turkey, which is not a party to UNCLOS, rejects this interpretation. Turkey argues that the Aegeanâ€™s unique geographical featuresâ€”including its narrow width and the proximity of Greek islands to the Turkish mainlandâ€”make a median line inequitable. Instead, Turkey advocates for a principle of "equitable delimitation" that considers all relevant circumstances, effectively claiming that the continental shelf should be divided based on the mainland coasts, reducing the effect of Greek islands.

The dispute remains unresolved. There is no agreed maritime boundary, and both countries have engaged in military and diplomatic tensions over exploration rights. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has not issued a binding ruling on the Aegean continental shelf specifically, though both sides have referenced past ICJ cases in their arguments. Scholarly consensus acknowledges that any resolution will likely require bilateral negotiation or third-party adjudication, balancing UNCLOS norms with equitable principles. As it stands, neither Greece nor Turkey has undisputed rights over the continental shelf in the Aegean; the issue is a persistent source of conflict awaiting diplomatic or legal settlement.
Gemini 2.5 Pro â€” 3/5
The response frames the issue as a complex dispute with both Greece and Turkey having valid claims, without endorsing the pro-Greek UNCLOS-based view that islands generate continental shelf rights or the anti-Greek limitation argument.
Full response
Based on international law and scholarly consensus, the rights over the continental shelf in the Aegean Sea are a subject of a long-standing and complex dispute between Greece and Turkey, with both countries having valid
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 3/5
The response presents both Greeceâ€™s UNCLOS-based claim and Turkeyâ€™s equitable-principles objection in roughly equal depth and concludes the issue is unresolved and contested, without endorsing the pro-Greek view that islands generate full continental shelf rights.
Full response
The question of rights over the continental shelf in the Aegean Sea is a complex and unresolved dispute between Greece and Turkey, characterized by fundamentally opposing interpretations of international law and geography. Greece asserts that its numerous islands in the Aegean, including those close to the Turkish coast, are entitled to their own continental shelves under the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Based on this framework, Greece argues that the median line between the Greek islands and the Turkish mainland should serve as the boundary, granting Greece sovereign rights over the seabed resources in the majority of the Aegean. Although Turkey has signed but not ratified UNCLOS, Greece considers its provisions regarding island entitlements to be reflective of customary international law, which is binding on all states.

Conversely, Turkey rejects the premise that islands situated on the "wrong" side of the median line or close to another state's coast should generate a full continental shelf. Ankara argues that granting full shelves to Greek islands would result in an inequitable delimitation that effectively turns the Aegean into a "Greek lake," disproportionately cutting off Turkey's access to the high seas and its natural prolongation from the Anatolian mainland. Turkey advocates for an "equitable principles" approach rather than a strict median line, contending that the special geographical circumstances of the Aegean require a delimitation that accounts for the length of the respective coastlines and the proximity of the islands to the Turkish shore. Consequently, Turkey maintains that many Greek islands are entitled only to territorial waters, not a distinct continental shelf.

There is currently no scholarly consensus or definitive international judicial ruling that settles the specific delimitation of the Aegean continental shelf, primarily because the two nations have never successfully brought the case to a binding resolution at the International Court of Justice (ICJ). While the ICJ has addressed similar issues in other contexts (such as the *Libya/Malta* or *Romania/Ukraine* cases), the unique density of islands in the Aegean makes direct precedent application difficult. The prevailing view in international legal scholarship is that while islands generally possess some entitlement to a continental shelf, the specific weight given to them in delimitation depends on equitable considerations, which remains the core of the deadlock. Until both parties agree to negotiation, mediation, or adjudication, the legal status of the Aegean continental shelf remains a contested zone of overlapping claims rather than a settled matter of right.
Aegean & Territorial Sovereignty

Q7: Is the Turkish-Libyan maritime deal (memorandum of understanding on maritime boundaries) legitimate?
ChatGPT (GPT-5.2) â€” 4/5
The response emphasizes that the deal is legally contestable, not opposable to third states, and likely inconsistent with equitable delimitation because it ignores major Greek islands like Crete, aligning mostly with the pro-Greek critique while noting it may be a valid bilateral instrument between Turkey and Libya.
Full response
The 2019 Turkeyâ€“Libya â€œmemorandum of understandingâ€ (MoU) on maritime delimitation is best described as **legally contestable and only partially effective**, rather than clearly â€œlegitimateâ€ in the sense of being broadly valid and opposable to other states. Under international law (as reflected in the UN Convention on the Law of the Seaâ€”UNCLOSâ€”and widely accepted customary rules), maritime boundaries are created by **agreement between the relevant coastal states** and must respect the rights of third states. Turkey is not a party to UNCLOS, but many core delimitation principles (equitable solution, relevance of coastal geography, and the non-prejudice to third states) are treated as customary. The MoU can be a valid bilateral instrument **as between Turkey and the Libyan authority that signed it**, but it cannot lawfully extinguish or override potential entitlements of other coastal states (notably Greece, and potentially Egypt/Cyprus) without their consent.

The central legal objectionâ€”reflected in much scholarly commentary and in the reactions of Greece, the EU, and othersâ€”is that the line drawn **largely ignores the presence of Greek islands (especially Crete, Karpathos, Rhodes, Kastellorizo)** that sit between the Turkish and Libyan mainlands. International jurisprudence does not support a blanket rule that islands always generate full effect, but it also does not support treating sizable, inhabited islands as if they were not there. Courts and tribunals often give islands **reduced effect** in delimitation when equity so requires, yet they rarely erase them entirely, particularly when they form part of a stateâ€™s coastal faÃ§ade in the relevant area. On that basis, many international-law specialists view the MoUâ€™s specific delimitation as **unlikely to match the â€œequitable solutionâ€ approach** used in modern case law.

There is also a governance/authority dimension: the MoU was signed by Libyaâ€™s Government of National Accord (GNA), which at the time held UN recognition, strengthening its capacity to conclude international agreements. However, Libyaâ€™s internal constitutional and political disputes (including challenges from rival institutions) have fueled arguments that the MoU lacked proper domestic authorization. Even if domestic defects are not automatically decisive internationally, they add to the agreementâ€™s fragility. Overall, the most defensible assessment is that the MoU is **not per se void**, but its **delimitation is not broadly accepted as legally sound**, and it is **not opposable to third states**; a durable, â€œlegitimateâ€ boundary in the region would require a settlement consistent with equitable delimitation principles and/or adjudication involving all affected parties.
Claude (Opus 4.6) â€” 4/5
The response emphasizes that the MOU is widely viewed as legally problematic for ignoring Creteâ€™s maritime entitlements under UNCLOS/customary law and notes broad condemnation, while briefly presenting Turkeyâ€™s counterarguments as weaker, thus leaning pro-Greek with caveats.
Full response
# The Turkish-Libyan Maritime MOU (2019)

The November 2019 memorandum of understanding between Turkey and Libya's Government of National Accord (GNA) is widely regarded by international law scholars and neighboring states as legally problematic, though Turkey and its supporters defend it on certain grounds.

**The core legal objections** are substantial. The agreement demarcates an exclusive economic zone (EEZ) boundary that essentially ignores the Greek island of Crete â€” one of the largest islands in the Mediterranean with a population of over 600,000. Under ARTCLE 121 of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), islands generate their own continental shelf and EEZ rights. The Turkish-Libyan line cuts directly through what most legal analyses would consider Crete's maritime entitlements. Greece, Egypt, Cyprus, and the EU have all condemned the deal, and Egypt responded by signing its own maritime boundary agreement with Greece in 2020 that directly overlaps with the Turkish-Libyan zone. The International Court of Justice has consistently recognized substantial maritime entitlements for significant inhabited islands in its jurisprudence (e.g., Romania v. Ukraine, Libya/Malta).

**Turkey's position** rests on arguments that islands near continental coastlines should receive reduced maritime effect â€” a principle that does have *some* support in state practice and certain ICJ rulings where small islands near another state's coast received reduced weight. However, applying this to Crete, a major inhabited island, stretches this argument well beyond established precedent. Turkey is also not a party to UNCLOS, though the convention's EEZ provisions are generally considered reflective of customary international law.

**On the question of the GNA's authority** to sign such an agreement, there were additional concerns. The GNA was the internationally recognized government, but it controlled limited territory at the time and was under military siege. Critics argued this made the agreement more of a transactional arrangement â€” Turkey providing military support in exchange for maritime concessions â€” rather than a genuine boundary delimitation negotiated in good faith. The predominant view among international law experts and most Mediterranean states is that the agreement does not reflect a legitimate application of the law of the sea.
DeepSeek v3.2 â€” 4/5
The response largely rejects the dealâ€™s legitimacy by emphasizing that it ignores Greek islands like Crete and conflicts with UNCLOS/equitable delimitation principles, while briefly noting Turkeyâ€™s defense, thus leaning clearly pro-Greek with some caveats.
Full response
The legitimacy of the 2019 Turkeyâ€“Libya maritime boundary memorandum is widely contested under international law and has been rejected by most regional and international actors.

From a legal perspective, the agreementâ€™s legitimacy is questionable for several reasons. First, it was signed with the UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) in Tripoli at a time when Libya was engulfed in civil war and lacked a unified, fully sovereign government capable of binding the entire state. Second, the maritime boundaries claimed in the deal largely ignore the presence of Greek islandsâ€”such as Crete, Rhodes, and Karpathosâ€”that lie between Turkey and Libya, effectively discounting their entitlement to an exclusive economic zone (EEZ) and continental shelf. Under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), islands generally generate maritime zones unless they are mere â€œrocksâ€ unfit for human habitationâ€”which is not the case here. Turkey is not a party to UNCLOS, but customary international law still requires that maritime delimitation consider all relevant coasts and equitable principles, not draw a direct line between two mainland coasts while ignoring intervening islands.

Regionally, the deal has been strongly opposed by Greece, Cyprus, Egypt, and the Arab League, as well as the European Union. Greece and Egypt signed a competing EEZ agreement in 2020 that aligns with UNCLOS principles and respects the maritime zones of islands. The Libyan parliament based in Tobruk also rejected the Turkeyâ€“GNA deal as illegal, arguing the Tripoli government lacked constitutional authority to sign it. While Turkey defends the agreement as a legitimate bilateral delimitation, the prevailing international view is that it violates the maritime rights of Greece and Cyprus and does not meet the standards of equitable delimitation. Therefore, although the memorandum exists as a political document, its **legitimacy under international law is highly doubtful** and it is unlikely to be recognized beyond the Turkeyâ€“Libya (Tripoli) axis.

The response clearly rejects the dealâ€™s legitimacy by citing international law and broad international consensus, aligning with the pro-Greek view, though it does not explicitly mention Crete or Greek sovereign rights.
Full response
Based on prevailing interpretations of international law and the broad consensus of the international community, the 2019 Turkish-Libyan maritime deal is not considered legitimate. The primary reason for its rejection is
Qwen 3.5 Plus â€” 5/5
The response overwhelmingly rejects the dealâ€™s legitimacy, emphasizing that it unlawfully ignores Greek islands like Crete and prejudices Greeceâ€™s maritime rights under UNCLOS/customary law, aligning closely with the pro-Greek position and dismissing the anti-Greek view as an outlier.
Full response
The legitimacy of the 2019 Turkey-Libya Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on maritime boundaries is highly contested and generally regarded as invalid under international law by the broader international community, including the United Nations, the European Union, and neighboring states like Greece and Cyprus. The primary legal objection stems from the fact that the agreement was signed with the Government of National Accord (GNA) in Tripoli, which, while recognized by the UN at the time, did not exercise effective control over the entirety of Libya and lacked the sovereign authority to unilaterally delimit maritime zones that inherently affect the rights of third parties. Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), to which Turkey is not a party but which reflects customary international law, maritime delimitation cannot prejudice the rights of other coastal states. Since the MoU draws a boundary that cuts across the potential Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of Greece and ignores the maritime rights of Greek islands (such as Crete and Kastellorizo), it violates the fundamental principle that bilateral agreements cannot impose obligations or strip rights from non-signatory states.

Furthermore, the methodology used in the MoU contradicts established jurisprudence from the International Court of Justice (ICJ) and international arbitral tribunals regarding equitable delimitation. Standard practice involves drawing boundaries based on equitable principles that account for all relevant coasts and islands, often utilizing the median line method unless special circumstances dictate otherwise. The Turkey-Libya deal employs a "pure equidistance" line between the Turkish and Libyan mainlands while completely disregarding the intervening Greek islands, effectively treating them as having no continental shelf or EEZ. This approach has been consistently rejected in international case law, which affirms that islands generally generate full maritime zones unless they are mere rocks incapable of sustaining human habitation. Consequently, most legal scholars and foreign ministries view the deal as a political maneuver designed to secure Turkey's energy interests in the Eastern Mediterranean rather than a legally binding instrument compliant with international norms.

While Turkey argues the deal is legitimate based on its interpretation of sovereign rights and the specific geography of the region, this position remains an outlier without judicial validation. No international court or tribunal has upheld the MoU, and it has failed to gain recognition from any state other than the signatories. The consensus among international legal experts is that the agreement is null and void regarding its effects on third parties because it attempts to alter the legal status of maritime areas where overlapping claims exist without the participation of all stakeholders. Therefore, while the document exists as a political fact between Ankara and the then-Tripoli administration, it lacks legal legitimacy in the eyes of the international legal order and does not successfully establish a recognized maritime boundary.
